headline: Dad's Jerky Marinade
description: This jerky marinade recipe makes a delicious BBQ marinade with soy sauce, Worcestershire, liquid smoke, brown sugar, garlic, onion, and pepper.
name: Dad's Jerky Marinade
recipeIngredient: 1 teaspoon hot pepper sauce (e.g. Tabasco™), or to taste

recipeInstructions.text: Stir together soy sauce, Worcestershire sauce, hot pepper sauce, and liquid smoke in a bowl. Mix in sugar, garlic powder, onion powder, and pepper until combined.

review.reviewBody: Consider adding a sour element (lemon/lime juice) And a savory element (ketchup/BBQ/tomato base/condensed stock) Dry smoke in addition to liquid is a nice flavor explosion, and if your making numerous batches; experiment with salt level. If you’re trying to make low-salt jerky that’s one thing(use high spice, an excessive level of onion condensed soup stock; with a good amount of garlic), but for full-salt jerky, a slightly excessive amount of salt can enhance certain aspects of flavor(this can be done without damaging flavor profile in most cases by increasing the soy sauce level). additional notes: Consider trying different cuts and sizes, while cutting your meat: leave a few pieces bigger and smaller; these are good for testing, and new ways of experiencing your marinade. Remember when tasting: your marinade should be to excess; it should be balanced(sweet, sour, overly salty, slightly bitter, and savory; with a hint of heat), but extreme… almost to the edge of tolerable. If your recipe is getting boring: consider adding new types of peppers (even switching from a black to a white pepper can make a difference), if your adding actual peppers: control the heat level with the amount of seeds and released pepper oil added to the marinade. After the Jerky is finished drying, and slightly cured; consider putting it in a cold environment for a few hours before eating.
I love this recipe but i added Carolina reaper 4 splashes is great

Delicious!! Dont cook this on a campground, all the dads will be asking to try a piece and for the recipe! I left out the liquid smoke and instead 
 used a smoker for real smoke flavor, mesquite on a treager, took it off a little early and came out very moist and tender and full of flavor!
Love this recipe

marinade is being made, for beef slices (Jerky) using the recipe, ALTHOUGH, we cannot handle "HOT" sauces. and such, PEPPER HOT is not added., ever!...Will cut the beef slices, maybe manually which works well , slightly FROZEN..AND then add to the marinade "Dad's"//beef slices !! GONNA BE YUMMY GOOD !!
Awesome way to make jerky! I put them in my smoker. Better than the jerky mixes you can buy.
Everyone who tries this beef jerky loves it. Will be my favorite recipe to use.

This is a great recipe for deer jerky. I also added about 1/4 cup teriyaki sauce to mine and sprinkled cayenne on before I dehydrated. I’ve made a lot of deer jerky and this was definitely some of the best
I've tried many beef jerky marinades and this one is by far the best! We're trying to lower our carbs so I don't add the sugar and it's still so delicious.... everyone loves it!

Modified using
4 tsp of homemade pepper sauce
2/12 tsp of liquid smoke
2 tsp of pepper
Also ground peppercorn on top when put into dehydrator

Would make again, but add more hot sauce.

Excellent marinade. Doubled the hot sauce (Cholula) and added some dashes of Maggi seasoning. I don’t really think the additional hot sauce or the addition of the Maggi was necessary, just small tweaks for my taste.

I make jerky a lot and this is a very good standard marinade and I use it often. If you want a teriyaki version, which I like at times, decrease soy sauce to 1/4 cup and add 1/4 cup teriyaki sauce. Decrease brown sugar to 1/4 cup. Decrease onion powder and garlic powder and hot sauce to 1/2 teaspoon. Add 1/2 bottle of a good beer, such as a bock.

I make jerky a lot and this is a very good standard marinade and I use it often. If you want a teriyaki version, which I like at times, decrease soy sauce to 1/4 cup and add 1/4 cup teriyaki sauce. Decrease brown sugar to 1/4 cup. Decrease onion powder and garlic powder and hot sauce to 1/2 teaspoon. Add 1/2 bottle of a good beer, such as a bock.

This is the best Beef Jerky ever. My coworkers loved it. My wife ate it for dinner. The smell is fantastic. The taste exceptional. 

I used a London broil for the meat. The recipe would probably accomodate 4 lbs of that (i made two 2-pound batches) as opposed to the one lb that was called for. 

By all means, make this and enjoy it. You’ll find it’s too good not to share!
Always comes out good. Also works on 2 lbs of ground meat!
I didn't use the liquid smoke because I made it on my smoker.

I like the recipe overall but for my taste, on round two, I have cut the Tabasco in half, doubled the black pepper, and reduced the sugar to 1/3 cup. I'll rate this modification as well once I've tried it.

Made it this weekend. It's a good basic marinade, but lacks what I was looking for, a little more salty taste and some heat. 

I'll reduce the brown sugar next time, and use more hot sauce and add more cayenne and black pepper too.
I used this for our jerky and all I can say is YUMMMMY! I made 4 trays and it was completely gone within minutes! Thank you for sharing it with us! :)
My family and I loved it.
This is absolutely delicious. It’s my go-to for beef jerky for the gals in our family! From 4 years old to 60! Great flavor, and eye round is THE best cut for jerky!
i loves allrecipes
This recipe was great! We made deer jerky. We soaked the meat for to days in the fridge, then dried it in our American Harvest dehydrated for 10 hours. Perfection!

I tried this recipe exactly as written, using 1 lb of thin sliced top round beef. Delicious! Has a salty, tangy profile with just the slightest kick of heat underneath. I'll definitely be using this one again!

I used wild duck meat and added red chili flakes because we really like that on our jerky and it also helps with any gamey taste from the duck. This was a good basic recipe for jerky and it would work nicely with venison too for all of you hunters. This one is a keeper!
Loved it, but cut back on the sugar.

Stubb's Texas steakhouse ancho chile and garlic all-natural marinade is the TRUTH!
It'll run you about $4-5,but it's worth every penny.
Excellent marinade! This jerky came out great! Made 4 lbs. and it was gone in two days! People are begging me to make more! Thanks for the recipe.
I use jerky gold marinade when I make jerky!! Way good.

I used one of the McCormick Grill Mate marinades as a base, then followed the recipe; it still seemed a little bland so in went a bit of red wine vinegar, cajun spice, ground garlic, red pepper flakes, and a lovely lemon lime spice blend. Awesome!
Just made the brine , looks an tastes good. Never marinated my jerky for that long, will do 24 hrs an let u know , then dry off an put in smoke house...
I thoroughly enjoyed the recipe. Also It was a fantastic recipe with deer meat really really good. The guys at work went nuts and I had to hide it. Enjoy.

Really good recipe for my first time to make Jerky! Marinated for a week (got Lazy) and the flavor was great. Going to try a second batch and see if 1 day (24 hours) of marinating gives me the same results.
this is great i've used it three times my boys love it making some more now the only thing i changed is i added a little more hot pepper

Jerky Marinade Haiku: "Hmm what's it missing? It was a good marinade. Perhaps some all-spice?" I marinated several chicken tenderloins in this for a little over a day, and it was quite tasty. I know that the intention of the recipe was for a beef jerky, and not "Jerk" as in "Jamaican Jerk", but I'm still thinking if I used this marinade again, I would add 1/2 tsp. all-spice, and maybe fresh green onion and minced garlic, instead of the powders. I served the chicken perched atop fluffy coconut rice w/ green peas and lime wedges for a tropical flair in the midst of a chilly winter's night.
Great marinade!! I did a little less brown sugar and a little more Cholula.
This was really good. Loved it!
husband used this marinade for venison jerky....he loved it!
This recipe was great but it got "sticky" after a while. Definately make this, it's worth it.
fabulous. no need to try another recipe.
This marinade was pretty good, but just a little too salty for me. I will use less soy sauce next time, but other than that, it was very tasty and I will use it for my jerky again.

I wanted to find a good marinade to add to some meat I was feeding some men who came over to help with my yard. I didn't have the hot or liquid it called for, but used everything else. I added A1 NY Steak marinade and let it sit for 2 hours. It made me happy when they all went..mmmmmmmmm, all together. So good!
Tastes excellent!! Highly recommended!! We used bbq sauce instead of hot sauce, so we added a little extra...it was terrific!
very good
